title: Assessing the Practice and Potential of Situated Social Learning in the Work of Building Sustainable Communities
abstractText:
The production of sustainable communities means that professionals associated with the built environment and regeneration need to work out ways of shaping our towns and cities differently from how it has been done in the past. The aim of this project is to establish how professionals working in regeneration and renewal fields (such as town planners, housing managers or regeneration workers) learn to adapt their ways of working and how these lessons are remembered in the multi-disciplinary teams in which they work. Given that learning ‘on the job’ is a significant source of learning, it is vital to understand how professionals learn in teams and as teams in everyday environments.

The research will work with a small number of professionals in multi-disciplinary teams to see what is learnt and how learning is remembered by individuals and teams building sustainable communities. The project will work with the RTPI and the regional centre of excellence in the South West (Creating: Excellence) in building a better understanding of the conditions under which learning on the job occurs and hence will help to inform how professional bodies (such as the RTPI) might think about lifelong learning in the built environment.
organisation: University of the West of England
